awd_titl_txt: Dissertation Research: Mechanisms of soil organic carbon interactions with black carbon
awd_abstract_narration:
Increasing levels of carbon dioxide in the Earth's atmosphere are driving global climate change. Because soils currently hold more organic carbon than is present as carbon in the atmosphere, soil management can affect rates of global climate change.  Pyrogenic carbon is a form of soil carbon that is produced naturally during fires that can be difficult for microbes to decompose.  Under some circumstance, this pyrogenic carbon ("biochar") may increase carbon storage and thus reduce the amount of carbon that is emitted to the atmosphere from soils. In order to predict the effects of pyrogenic carbon on soil carbon balance, proposed research will expand existing work to look at the importance of microbes and soil type in determining whether addition of pyrogenic carbon increases soil carbon storage. Methods will include a soil incubation experiment, where diverse soil types from across the United States will be mixed with pyrogenic carbon to predict the effects of pyrogenic carbon on soil organic carbon storage under a variety of conditions. This will help improve national and global efforts to model and predict the natural organic carbon cycle and will provide information that can be useful for land management decisions, especially those where prescribed burning is an option.  In addition to these impacts, the research will support a PhD student's research, train undergraduate students in research, and engage the public with organic carbon cycle science, through lectures, general interest articles, a research website, and professional meetings.

Pyrogenic C (PyC) can comprise a large fraction of the soil organic carbon (SOC) in soils around the world, with levels up to 50-80% of SOC in some ecosystems. The effects of PyC additions on already existing SOC are still poorly understood. PyC additions to soil have been found to both increase and decrease SOC decomposition, with the magnitude and even direction of these interactions changing over time. These varied responses indicate that multiple mechanisms are occurring, with different mechanisms potentially acting over different timescales. The researchers will use experimental manipulations to determine whether varying the amount of labile OC in PyC and in SOC can predict the magnitude and direction of any priming effects, using 13C-labelled BC. This doctoral dissertation improvement grant will expand current experiments to a nationally representative set of soil types and will test the hypothesis that microbial community composition (analysed using high-throughput sequencing) can be used to predict PyC-SOC interactions. Understanding these mechanisms is essential to predict the impact of natural PyC inputs to soils on the global C cycle, and to quantifying the net climate impact of intentional PyC production and management.

por.por_cntn:
Background: Soil carbon (C) is a critical and active pool in the global C cycle. Of this soil C pool, pyrogenic organic matter (PyOM) produced during fires can comprise a large fraction (up to 50-80% in some ecosystems). Because PyOM is relatively difficult for microbes to decompose, its input to soils has the potential to directly increase soil C stocks. Indeed, intentional production of PyOM and its addition to soils for C management, potentially on a global scale, have been proposed as a mechanism to mitigate climate change. However, the effects of PyOM additions on non-pyrogenic soil organic carbon (SOC) are still poorly characterized. PyOM additions to soil have been found to both increase and decrease SOC decomposition, with the magnitude and even direction of these interactions changing over time. These varied responses indicate that multiple mechanisms are occurring, with different mechanisms potentially acting over different timescales. This doctoral dissertation improvement grant expanded field and lab experiments to a nationally diverse set of soils and tested the hypothesis that microbial communities and SOC decomposition rates can predict PyOM-SOC interactions, using high-throughput sequencing.

Approach: We used five contrasting soil samples from NEON sites across the US. We added corn stover organic matter (OM), pyrogenic organic matter (PyOM) charred at 350°C, or no additions, and incubated soils for one month, tracing their CO2 emissions continuously and analysing the microbial community at three timepoints.

Key Outcomes:

Question 1: Are soils with harder-to-decompose SOC more prone to stimulation by PyOM additions?

We found that the soils with the lowest baseline CO2 emission rates were those that had the lowest initial SOC (NY, UT, FL), although on a per-g-SOC basis, they had the highest emissions. These soils were also the most prone to increased C losses with PyOM or OM additions. Thus, soils with low total emissions but high relative emissions as a fraction of their total C content may be most at risk of increased C losses with PyOM or OM additions. This could suggest that soil microbes in these systems were C-limited, so the addition of OM and, to a lesser extent, PyOM increased soil microbial activity, increasing SOC mineralization rates.

Question 2: Do soil microbial communities reflect changes in SOC mineralization with PyOM additions?

Soil microbial communities remained significantly different across soils throughout the month-long experiment. The soils that increased CO2 emissions the most with OM or PyOM additions also showed the greatest changes in the microbial community composition. This suggests that the increases in SOC mineralization observed with PyOM additions in Question 1 were not simply due to generally increased microbial activity, but also associated with a shift in the microbial community composition. Soils with higher CO2 emissions (e.g., AK or HI, or those with OM additions) tended to have more bacteria from the Firmicutes phylum. This is consistent with the fact that Firmicutes includes many spore-forming bacteria, which may be the first to respond to warm, moist conditions of the incubation. A contrasting phylum is the Acidobacteria, which generally increased in relative abundance over the duration of the experiment, and were highest in the unamended soils. These results are consistent with and expand upon results from a field trial from Co-PI Whitman's other dissertation work, and future work will delve more deeply into the specific taxa that are responsive to PyOM and OM additions to soil.

Intellectual merit: This research will enhance understanding of the complex mechanisms driving PyOM and SOC interactions and their impact on the global C cycle. Making connections between soil function (changes to SOC mineralization with PyOM additions) and microbial community structure will advance the way we conceptualize these interactions. An improved mechanistic understanding of SOC-PyOM decomposition interactions will improve predictions of how natural or anthropogenic PyOM additions to soil affect soil C dynamics, informing land management and understanding of the global C cycle. This, in turn, could help inform future C cycling models, allowing for more robust predictions and management choices. This research will also yield relevant information for those interested in intentionally producing PyOM and applying it to soils as an agricultural soil amendment or as part of a C management strategy (in which case it is often referred to as “biochar”).

Broader impacts: Over the course of this grant, Co-PI Whitman presented 10 related posters or oral presentations at scientific conferences, farmer field days, and university seminars open to the public. She also developed skills in collaboration and project management during outreach to all NEON site collaborators. In addition, four papers of related dissertation work were published, two peer-reviewed book chapters related to this research were co-authored, and Co-PIs Whitman and Lehmann both maintain research websites accessible to the general public. Finally, a manuscript covering the full findings of this research is in preparation for submission to a scientific journal.
